title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on winnings from state lotteries or gambling establishments to ensure payment of child support arrearages. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act allows for the suspension of lottery or gambling winnings to pay child support arrearages. Payments can be withheld and paid to the state child support enforcement agency for distribution. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act allows for the suspension of payments under insurance policies or settlements to pay child support arrearages. Payments can be withheld and paid to the state child support enforcement agency for distribution after an inquiry is made. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act allows for the withholding of payments to pay child support arrearages. The payor must withhold the lesser of the payment amount or the arrearage amount and pay it to the state agency for distribution. The payor must withhold the payment amount or arrearage amount and pay it to the state agency for distribution. In any court action, payment must be suspended until the state agency confirms if the recipient owes child support arrears. The payor must withhold and pay the arrearage amount to the state agency for distribution. If the recipient owes child support arrears, the payment must be suspended until confirmed by the state agency. If the State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal conviction, they must hold it until the state agency confirms if the person owes child support arrears. The State agency must confirm if a person owes child support arrears before selling forfeited property from a criminal conviction. After deducting costs, the remaining proceeds from the sale of forfeited property are paid to the State agency to distribute, with any arrearage amount also paid directly to the agency for distribution in respect to a decedent. Any person required to make payment in respect to a decedent must suspend the payment until an inquiry is made to the State agency regarding child support arrearage. If there is an arrearage, the payment will be withheld to cover the amount owed. If there is a child support arrearage, the payment will be withheld to cover the amount owed and then paid to the State agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include restrictions on issuing or renewing occupational, professional, or business licenses for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. The amendment to Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act includes restrictions on issuing or renewing occupational, professional, or business licenses for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. An individual who is delinquent in child support payment will have a hold on their license until the support is paid or consent is given by a State prosecutor or court for the release of the hold. The amendment to Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act restricts issuing or renewing licenses for noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants. The State motor vehicle department cannot issue or renew driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with unpaid child support, unless a court or enforcement agency consents to release the hold on the license. The State motor vehicle department cannot issue or renew driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants. The State motor vehicle department must suspend driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for individuals with child support warrants until the warrant is removed. The State motor vehicle department must suspend driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for individuals with child support warrants until the warrant is removed. Additionally, a temporary license or vehicle registration may be granted to the individual pending compliance with the order or the removal of the warrant. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)) is amended to allow seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears. Seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages can be done through an administrative process, with notice and an opportunity to be heard, as per amended Section 466(a) of the Act. If the account holder fails to challenge the seizure successfully, the institution may have to pay as required by State law. The amended Section 466(a) of the Act allows for seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages. If the account holder fails to challenge the seizure successfully, the institution may have to pay the arrearage amount or the amount on deposit in the account to the entity with the right to collect. SEC. 5. REPORTING OF CHILD SUPPORT OBLIGATIONS TO CREDIT BUREAUS. Section 466(a)(7) of the Social Security Act is amended to require courts or administrative agencies to report child support orders to consumer reporting agencies. The amendment requires courts or administrative agencies to report child support orders to consumer reporting agencies, including the individual's name and the amount of the obligation. The amendment to the Social Security Act imposes liability on parents for the financial support of their children if the individual is unable to provide such support. This does not apply if the State plan explicitly states otherwise.
